thread.title_full: Apple's Tim Cook sees 'massive change' for car business - Chicago Tribune

author: Phil Rosenthal
title: Apple's Tim Cook sees 'massive change' for car business - Chicago Tribune
text:
Although we're not living in a "Back to the Future" 2015 of flying cars, Apple boss Tim Cook sees the auto industry poised for major disruption just the same.
While steering clear of rumors that the tech titan might eventually produce its own cars, Cook will say only that he wants us "to have the iPhone kind of experience" in our vehicles.
One can only assume he does not mean we get a cracked windshield and a battery that constantly needs charging.
"What I see is that software becomes an increasingly important component of the car in the future," Cook said at the Wall Street Journal's WSJDLive tech conference this week in Laguna Beach, Calif., pointing to initiatives to develop self-driving technology and improve electric-powered motors that look to change more than a century of driving.
Cook, you see, almost certainly isn't content for Apple to push updates into our devices every few days to fix bugs and improve functionality with the Apple Watch we still have no intention of buying.
He wants it to be part of the push to update for the auto business because if Apple doesn't, someone else will.
"It would seem," he said, "like there would be massive change in that industry, massive change."
Apple's long-awaited, recently unveiled CarPlay system is a small step in this direction, enabling people to use their iPhones and car-specific apps for a range of uses, including entertainment, navigation, communication and information.

(Robert Duffer) "What we really want, hopefully in the short term, is, we'd like people as they enter their car to be able to have an iPhone experience in their car," Cook said. "I don't know what kind of car you have today. But whatever kind of car it is, the interface in it is probably not (among) the top 10 things you love about the car."
Apple could probably buy a carmaker if it wanted.
But utility and ease of use got iPhones into not just millions of pockets and purses but millions of lives, so Cook hopes CarPlay can get it into the car. The driver's seat can wait.
"CarPlay is being deployed in a number of the largest brands in the business right now," he said. "That's all about trying to make your life outside the car and your life inside the car be seamless."
Of course that was also part of the pitch for the Apple Watch, which Cook insists people who have love and can't do without, despite the fact that few who don't have it feel as though they're missing anything.
The idea of a car tethered to the wired world may appeal to many, but some drivers still like the idea of the solitude that comes from getting behind the wheel and getting out on the open road.
The rumble of the engine and the air whooshing by can almost make it seem like flying sometimes.
No, Siri. Apple cars may not be for everyone.
Margin call: Thomas Edison invented a workable electric incandescent light 136 years ago Wednesday at his laboratory in Menlo Park, N.J. When the idea of using carbonized cotton thread as a filament occurred to Edison, it's assumed a kerosene lamp lit up over his head.
